_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan-Executive Summary



Facility: Trotter Fertilizer and Propane

City: Ord, NE.

Contact:John Felton

Phone:308-728-7722



1. Facility Policy.

      The owners, management, and employees of Trotter Fertilizer and Propane are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, Valley County LEPC, and other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to persons and the environment.



2. Facility Information.

      The primary activity at the facility is the distribution of products to farmers.  The fertilizer product, anhydrous ammonia is stored and distributed for direct application as a nutrient for crop production.  Anhydrous ammonia is stored in nurse tanks designed for this purpose.    

      

3. The Worst-Case Release Scenario and the Alternate Release Scenario

      An analysis of the potential off-site consequences of hypothetical worst-case and alternative-case accidental releases have been addressed in our Hazard Assessment and information is in our Risk Management Program.



4.Accidental Release Prevention Program.

      The facility is in compliance with the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia" and our state regulations covering anhydrous ammonia.  The OSHA standard is referenced in this RMP Registration Form, see Section 8.3(b).



5. Five-year Accident History.

      There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the last five years that have caused any deaths, injuries or significant property damage at the facility; nor, to our knowledge, has THERE BEEN ANY ACCIDENTAL RELEASES resulting in off-site deaths, injuries, evacuation, property damage, or environmental damage.



6. Emergency Action Plan

      The facility has:

       a. A written emergency action plan, in acc

ordance with OSHA Standard 29 CFR 1910.38;     

       b. Provided state and local authorities with the emergency planning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA)

       c. If a large release of anhydrous ammonia takes place at the facility, the required response action is to evacuate the area of the spill and call 911 and all applicable emergency response numbers listed in our Emergency Action Plan. 



7. Planned Changes to Improve Safety.

     

     Safety Improvements are an on-going process at this facility. Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance and safe conditions of our equipment. There are no additional specific anhydrous ammonia safety recommendations at this time.
